Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Next-Generation Algorithms for Stochastic Spatial Simulation of Cell Polarization
Award.AbstractNarration:
Cell polarity, whereby cellular components that were previously uniformly distributed become asymmetrically localized, is essential to the diverse specialized functions of eukaryotic cells. A hallmark of cell polarity is spatial localization. From a modeling point of view, spatial localization cannot be understood without proper modeling of the spatial dynamics governing its creation and time evolution. At the same time, spatial dynamics are profoundly influenced by stochastic events that manifest as cellular noise. Therefore, deep understanding of cell polarity inevitably requires the proper modeling, simulation, and analysis of stochastic spatial dynamics. The fundamental problem limiting work in this area in the past has been the computational complexity of stochastic spatial simulations. This project develops the experimental data and algorithms for modeling, simulation and analysis of spatial stochastic dynamics arising in cell polarity in the yeast pheromone response system. A novel algorithm is developed to address the computationally intensive task of spatial stochastic simulation. The algorithm is then further developed and then integrated into a powerful software infrastructure to enable its widespread use. Experiments capable of capturing stochastic variability inform model development and analysis.

Software developed as a result of this project enables routine simulation of highly complex spatial stochastic phenomena across the sciences and engineering. All software will be made widely available. Tutorial courses and presentations at meetings and workshops will be given to ensure the accessibility of the research. Graduate students involved in this project are provided with a unique, highly multidisciplinary research experience. Students at UCSB work as a tightly-knit team co-advised by Petzold and Khammash, with extended visits to UCI to work in Yi's experimental lab, learning about the possibilities and limitations of the experimental techniques. UCI students focused on experiment spend significant time at UCSB working with the modelers, learning first-hand what the systems-level approach can bring to biological research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The breaking of symmetry during cell polarization is a fundamental process in all living organisms. It is how neurons form synapses, how neutrophils track down invading bacteria, and how different organ systems develop specialized asymmetric structures. One classic example is yeast mating which served as our model system for these studies. Quite surprisingly we demonstrated that stochastic (random) dynamics play a major role in cell polarization through a novel process we term spatial stochastic amplification.

The key idea is that discrete, random events combine with positive feedback to create a specific site on the membrane to grow a mating projection. In this manner an isotropic system develops asymmetry. This process can be guided by an external cue such as a chemical gradient of mating pheromone so that the resulting projection grows up the gradient in a directional manner.

One surprise is the high degree of stochasticity in these systems, and the manner in which this randomness is exploited to enhance polarization. We have shown that we can describe experimental observations only with spatial stochastic simulations, but not with their deterministic counterparts. This fundamental insight highlights the need for representing spatial stochastics when investigating biological systems.

The modeling and simulations led to a prediction of a novel positive feedback loop in the yeast mating signaling pathway, as well as a previously uncharacterized function for a key protein that forms the glue of a specialized structure (polarisome) at the tip of the mating projection. Through a series of experiments we characterized this positive feedback loop and demonstrated its importance for successful polarization. Experiments and computer modeling demonstrated how interactions between the positive feedback and the spatial stochastic dynamics generate spatial amplification.

Finally, we have developed the computational infrastructure including access to cloud computing resources to perform spatial stochastic simulations in other biological systems. Spatial sochastic simulations are notoriously slow, and we have developed algorithms to make the computations more efficient. In this manner, our results, models, and tools will together benefit the broader community as a combined package.
